--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> >From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...>
> >
> >John, thanks for the unhyped explanation of Thaler.  Admittedly, I
> >know nothing about it otherwise, but from your description it 
sounds
> >like simple hill climbing, i.e. make a tweak, see if you improved,
> >and if not go back to where you were.  Is there any real
> >difference?  Hill climbing is known to get stuck on local
> >optima...well that's an understatenent...it *does* get stuck on
> >local optima.  That's one reason having a population is helpful.
> >So I am just wondering how Thaler's thing differs from hill 
climbing?
> 
> As far as I have gathered, it isn't.  But because he is climbing 
the CURRENT 
> hill, he may avoid some of those pitfalls.  Instead of taking a 
look at the 
> landscape of 100 input samples and then walking in the 'average' 
uphill, it 
> walks up the hill of the current situation.  For a real-world 
situation, the 
> fitness landscape would tend to move fairly smoothly, shifting the 
peak (for 
> example) left and right, and so the hill climber is constantly 
following 
> that peak.  Yes, it could get caught in a local optima...until it 
finds a 
> situation in which that optima is far from optimal, which could 
jolt it out 
> of that optima with enough force to let it find a better optima 
somewhere 
> else.  That is how his robotic controller works, anyway.
> 

I think I'm still not getting something.  What's good about the 
current hill?  I thought the whole problem usually is to find the 
right hill with no prior information.  Is he assuming we already 
start with a solution?  And if so, then what's the point?  Just to 
track a slowly moving landscape?  There are probably better ways to 
do even that; for example, particle swarm optimization. 

I guess I'm missing the big picture.  His method wouldn't e.g. 
discover a biped walking network right?  It sounds like it just 
takes some preconstructed solution and gets "creative" on it by 
randomly messing it up and hoping something interesting pops out.  
Is that the big idea?

> The self-training network is nothing more than a network that 
implements 
> back-propagation on itself.  Not really that earth-shattering.
> 
> The creativity machine is nothing more than an exploration of the 
space 
> around the error-minimized solution.  The base network represents 
a 
> mathematical model of a problem space.  For a given input, it has 
a given 
> output.  But making minor tweaks to the model lets you explore the 
> surrounding environment.  You get things that are closely related 
to the 
> original model, with the mathematical shape of the tweak being 
almost the 
> same, but just enough different that you get a 'novel' output that 
is often 
> relevant and appropriate.
> 
> I think having a random input node would be an improvement even to 
Thaler's 
> work.  The connection weight will encapsulate the width of 
the 'relevance' 
> range that is viable to explore.  Then, the network will always 
tend to give 
> 'creative' but relevant output.
> 
> >I agree with what Derek later said...that site is so full of hype
> >and hyperbole that I can hardly believe this guy is really on the
> >ball and not just a nut.  But then again, they say genius is
> >difficult recognize...
> 
> Someone that is dependant on and trying to attract investors is 
left with 
> little choice.  They have to make a good impression on people with 
the cash. 
>   And what works on them doesn't always work on the people with 
the 
> knowledge and understanding of the work being done.  That, and 
what he is 
> doing is easily reproduced, which he would prefer not to have 
happen.  So he 
> doesn't spell out the details, for fear of being copied.  Can't 
blame the 
> guy for that. :)

I don't know, I'm still skeptical about his sanity.  I would expect 
technology investors to be paranoid about people who claim to have 
the ultimate solution to AI. 

Actually, interestingly, there was a guy I met an AI & Games 
conference who contacted me earlier in the year asking for my 
professional assessment of Thaler's work.  I didn't know anything 
about Thaler at the time, but I looked at his website and told the 
guy I couldn't evaluate it well because there isn't any technical 
information but that the claims sound unrealistic.  

All government funding agencies have grant reviews done by academic 
peers.  Are there really investors out there who put millions of 
dollars down without consulting an expert just because someone 
claims to have discovered the key to intelligence?
